description: From late Middle English appellacion, from Old French apellatiun, from Latin appellātiō (“a naming”).

entries.meaning: (formal or dated) A name or title by which someone is addressed or identified; a designation.
examples: "I'll not," retorted "Teeter" Nelson, whose first name was Harry, but who had gained his appellation because of a habit he had of "teetering" on his tiptoes when reciting in class. "I've got Peaches all right," and there was a struggle between the two lads, one trying to throw a snowball, and the other trying to prevent him.

entries.meaning: A geographical indication for wine that describes its geographic origin.
